intro: Convolvulus rugosus, commonly known as the rough morning glory, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is a herbaceous annual that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring hairy stems and lobed leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, funnel-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale purple, blooming from late spring to early autumn. Its flowers are often visited by pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance. The rough morning glory is often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides, thriving in full sun.
